sub_topic: Calculating the molar mass of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the molar mass of calcium nitrate, Ca(NO3)2, in grams per mole?
message_2:
To find the molar mass of calcium nitrate, Ca(NO3)2, we need to add the molar masses of each element in the compound.

Calcium (Ca): 1 atom × 40.08 g/mol = 40.08 g/mol
Nitrogen (N): 2 atoms × 14.01 g/mol = 28.02 g/mol (There are 2 nitrate ions, each containing 1 nitrogen atom)
Oxygen (O): 6 atoms × 16.00 g/mol = 96.00 g/mol (There are 2 nitrate ions, each containing 3 oxygen atoms)

Now, add the molar masses of each element together:

40.08 g/mol (Ca) + 28.02 g/mol (N) + 96.00 g/mol (O) = 164.10 g/mol

The molar mass of calcium nitrate, Ca(NO3)2, is 164.10 grams per mole.
